Owns the [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] | boards = }} '''Robert Young''' is a [[entrepreneurship|serial entrepreneur]] who is best known for founding [[Red Hat]] Inc., the open source software company. He also owns the franchise for the [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] of the [[Canadian Football League]] and serves as self-styled Caretaker of the team. He was born in [[Hamilton, Ontario]], Canada.{{cite web| title = Tiger-cats' Owner a Man of Many Hats| url = http://www.businessedge.ca/archives/article.cfm/tiger-cats-owner-a-man-of-many-hats-9424| accessdate = 2015-11-21| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151122075842/http://www.businessedge.ca/archives/article.cfm/tiger-cats-owner-a-man-of-many-hats-9424| archive-date = 2015-11-22| url-status = dead}} He attended [[Trinity College School]] in [[Port Hope, Ontario|Port Hope]], Ontario. He received a Bachelor of Arts from [[Victoria University in the University of Toronto|Victoria College]] at the [[University of Toronto]]. ==Career== Prior to [[Red Hat]], Young built a couple of computer rental and leasing businesses, including founding Vernon Computer Rentals in 1984.{{cite web|title = Ticats Biography: Bob Young| url=http://www.ticats.ca/page/bob-young| accessdate = 2012-01-05}} Descendants of Vernon are still operating under that name. After leaving Vernon, Young founded the ACC Corp Inc. in 1993.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/11/01/before-sale-to-ibm-for-billions-red-hat-started-in-cofounders-closet.html|title=Red Hat's co-founder was unemployed and working in a closet when he started the company IBM just bought for $34 billion|last=Jr|first=Tom Huddleston|date=2018-11-01|website=CNBC|language=en|access-date=2019-12-05}} [[Marc Ewing]] and Young co-founded open-source software company Red Hat. Red Hat was a member of the S&P 500 Index before being purchased by IBM on July 9, 2019. Marc Ewing and Young's partnership started in 1994 when ACC acquired the Red Hat trademarks from Ewing. In early 1995, ACC changed its name to Red Hat Software, which has subsequently been shortened to simply Red Hat, Inc. Young served as Red Hat's CEO until 1999. In 2002, Young founded [[Lulu.com]], a [[print-on-demand]], [[self-publishing]] company, and served as CEO. In 2006, Young established the Lulu Blooker Prize, a book prize for books that began as blogs. He launched the prize partly as a means to promote Lulu. Young served as CEO of [[PrecisionHawk]], a commercial drone technology company, from 2015 to 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://social.techcrunch.com/2017/01/25/blackboard-cofounder-michael-chasen-takes-ceo-reigns-at-precisionhawk/|title=Blackboard cofounder Michael Chasen takes CEO reins at PrecisionHawk}} Prior to being named PrecisionHawk's CEO in 2015, he was an early investor in the company. He continues to serve on its board as Chairman. Young also co-founded [[Linux Journal]] in 1994, and in 2003, he purchased the [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] of the [[Canadian Football League]]. Young focuses his philanthropic efforts on access to information and advancement of knowledge. In 1999, he co-founded [[Center for the Public Domain|The Center for the Public Domain]]. Young has supported the Creative Commons, [[Public Knowledge|Public Knowledge.org,]] the [[Dictionary of Old English]], Loran Scholarship Foundation, [[ibiblio.org]], and the NCSU eGames, among others. ==See also== * [[Center for the Public Domain]] * [[Red Hat]] * ''[[Linux Journal]]'' * [[Lulu (company)]] * [[ibiblio]] ==References== {{Commons category|Bob Young}} {{Reflist}} {{HamiltonTiCatsOwner}} {{Red Hat}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Young, Bob}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Ontario]] [[Category:Open source people]] [[Category:Red Hat people]] [[Category:University of Toronto alumni]] [[Category:People from Hamilton, Ontario]] [[Category:Hamilton Tiger-Cats owners]] [[Category:Forge FC non-playing staff]]
